data.title: Who will win the course?
data.solution:
tomStart = int(input())
tomSpeed = int(input())
jerrySpeed = int(input())
print(" "*tomStart+"T"+" "*(tomSpeed*10)+"T")
print("J"+" "*(jerrySpeed*10)+"J")
if tomStart+(tomSpeed*10)>=(jerrySpeed*10):print("Tom wins")
else:print("Jerry wins")
data.statement:
Tom and Jerry have a course of 10 iterations. Tom starts ahead of Jerry at the beginning of the race. You are given Tom's starting position [[tomStart]], while Jerry always begins at position 0. You are also given the speeds of both Tom and Jerry [[tomSpeed]] and [[jerrySpeed]]. You need to display each runner on the screen at the start and at the finish. Tom is represented by {{T}}, and Jerry by {{J}}. Finally, you need to determine the winner. If Tom wins, print {{Tom wins}}; otherwise, print {{Jerry wins}}. Jerry can only win if he is actually ahead of Tom. Distances on the course are filled with the space character; the leftmost character is at position 0, and the position increases to the right, 1 position per character.
For example, if Jerry starts at position 0 with a speed of 1, we have to represent him as mentioned: {{J}} follows by 10 spaces follows by {{J}}. Why do we print 10 spaces between the two {{J}}? Because After the race, Jerry was in position 10, and then he moved to position 11 to make room for the referee to measure the distance.

testCases.title: Test 1
testCases.testOut:
T          T
J          J
Tom wins

Tom wins

data.constraints:
[[tomStart]], [[tomSpeed]] and [[jerrySpeed]] are integers.
Start position is always different from the end position.
There will always be a winner and never a tie.

<<Line 3>>: The winner message.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Tom and Jerry have a course of 10 iterations. Tom starts ahead of Jerry at the beginning of the race. You are given Tom's starting position tomStart, while Jerry always begins at position 0. You are also given the speeds of both Tom and Jerry tomSpeed and jerrySpeed. You need to display each runner on the screen at the start and at the finish. Tom is represented by T, and Jerry by J. Finally, you need to determine the winner. If Tom wins, print Tom wins; otherwise, print Jerry wins. Jerry can only win if he is actually ahead of Tom. Distances on the course are filled with the space character; the leftmost character is at position 0, and the position increases to the right, 1 position per character.
For example, if Jerry starts at position 0 with a speed of 1, we have to represent him as mentioned: J follows by 10 spaces follows by J. Why do we print 10 spaces between the two J? Because After the race, Jerry was in position 10, and then he moved to position 11 to make room for the referee to measure the distance.
Input
Line 1: the start position of Tom tomStart
Line 2: the speed of Tom tomSpeed
Line 3: the speed of Jerry jerrySpeed
Output
Line 1: The representation of Tom at the begin and at the end of the course.
Line 2: The representation of Jerry at the begin and at the end of the course.
Line 3: The winner message.
Constraints
tomStart, tomSpeed and jerrySpeed are integers.
Start position is always different from the end position.
There will always be a winner and never a tie.
Example
Input
1
1
1
Output
 T          T
J          J
Tom wins
